DuckDuckGo
DuckDuckGo does not collect or share personal information. That is our privacy policy in a nutshell.
The rest of this page tries to explain why you should care
WHY YOU SHOULD CARE
SEARCH LEAKAGE
At other search engines
column2: when you do a search and then click on a link
column3: your search terms are sent to that site you clicked on (in the HTTP referrer header).

column1: We call this sharing of personal information "search leakage."
For example
column2: when you search for something private
column3: you are sharing that private search not only with your search engine

column1: but also with all the sites that you clicked on (for that search). ;NaN
In addition
column2: when you visit any site
column3: your computer automatically sends information about it to that site (including your User agent and IP address).

column1: This information can often be used to identify you directly.
So when you do that private search
column2: not only can those other sites know your search terms
column3: but they can also know that you searched it.

column1: It is this combination of available information about you that raises privacy concerns. ;NaN
DuckDuckGo prevents search leakage by default. Instead
column2: when you click on a link on our site
column3: we route (redirect) that request in such a way so that it does not send your search terms to other sites.

column1: The other sites will still know that you visited them
column2: but they will not know what search you entered beforehand.

column1: At some other search engines (including us)
column2: you can also use an encrypted version (HTTPS)
column3: which as a byproduct doesn't usually send your search terms to sites.

column1: However
column2: it is slower to connect to these versions and if you click on a site that also uses HTTPS then your search is sent. Nevertheless
column3: the encrypted version

column1: does protect your search from being leaked onto the computers it travels on between you and us. ;NaN
At DuckDuckGo
column2: our encrypted version goes even further and automatically changes links from a number of major Web sites to point to the encrypted versions of those sites.

column1: It is modeled after (and uses code from) the HTTPS Everywhere FireFox add-on. These sites include Wikipedia
column2: Facebook
column3: Twitter
column4: and Amazon to name a few.

column1: Another way to prevent search leakage is by using something called a POST request
column2: which has the effect of not showing your search in your browser
column3: and
column4: as a consequence
column5: does not send it to other sites.

column1: You can turn on POST requests on our settings page
column2: but it has its own issues. POST requests usually break browser back buttons
column3: and they make it impossible for you to easily share your search by copying and pasting it out of your Web browser's address bar.

column1: Finally
column2: if you want to prevent sites from knowing you visited them at all
column3: you can use a proxy like Tor. DuckDuckGo actually operates a Tor exit enclave
column4: which means you can get end to end anonymous and encrypted searching using Tor & DDG together.

column1: You can enter !proxy domain into DuckDuckGo as well
column2: and we will route you through a proxy
column3: e.g. !proxy breadpig.com. This feature is part of our !bang syntax.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: proxies can also be slow
column3: and free proxies (like the one we use) are funded by arguably excessive advertising. ;NaN

column1: Because of these drawbacks in HTTPS
column2: POST and proxies we decided to take the redirect approach to combat search leakage.

column1: However
column2: we leave the choice up to you. You can deviate from the default on our settings page by toggling the redirect or address bar settings.

column1: You can also use our encrypted version. ;NaN
SEARCH HISTORY
Other search engines save your search history. Usually your searches are saved along with the date and time of the search
some information about your computer (e.g. your IP address
column2: User agent and often a unique identifier stored in a browser cookie)

column1: and if you are logged in
column2: your account information (e.g. name and email address).

column1: With only the timestamp and computer information
column2: your searches can often be traced directly to you. With the additional account information
column3: they are associated directly with you.

column1: Also
column2: note that with this information your searches can be tied together. This means someone can see everything you've been searching
column3: not just one isolated search.

column1: You can usually find out a lot about a person from their search history.
It's sort of creepy that people at search engines can see all this info about you
column2: but that is not the main concern. ;NaN

column1: The main concern is when they either a) release it to the public or b) give it to law enforcement.
Why would they release it to the public? AOL famously released supposedly anonymous search terms for research purposes
except they didn't do a good job of making them completely anonymous
column2: and they were ultimately sued over it.

column1: In fact
column2: almost every attempt to anonymize data has similarly been later found out to be much less anonymous than initially thought.

column1: The other way to release it to the public is by accident. Search engines could lose data
column2: or get hacked
column3: or accidentally expose data due to security holes or incompetence
column4: all of which has happened with personal information on the Internet.

column1: Why would search engines give your search history to law enforcement? Simply because law enforcement asked for it
column2: usually as part of a legal investigation. If you read privacy policies and terms of service carefully you will notice that they say they can give your information on court order.

column1: This makes sense because they may be legally obligated to do so. However
column2: search engines are not legally obligated to collect personal information in the first place. They do it on their own volition.

column1: The bottom line is if search engines have your information
column2: it could get out
column3: even if they have the best intentions. And this information (your search history) can be pretty personal.

column1: For these reasons
column2: DuckDuckGo takes the approach to not collect any personal information. The decisions of whether and how to comply with law enforcement requests
column3: whether and how to anonymize data
column4: and how to best protect your information from hackers are out of our hands. Your search history is safe with us because it cannot be tied to you in any way.

column1: INFORMATION
INFORMATION NOT COLLECTED
When you search at DuckDuckGo
column2: we don't know who you are and there is no way to tie your searches together.

column1: When you access DuckDuckGo (or any Web site)
column2: your Web browser automatically sends information about your computer
column3: e.g. your User agent and IP address.

column1: Because this information could be used to link you to your searches
column2: we do not log (store) it at all. ;5

column1: This is a very unusual practice
column2: but we feel it is an important step to protect your privacy.

column1: It is unusual for a few reasons. First
column2: most server software auto-stores this information
column3: so you have to go out of your way not to store it.

column1: Second
column2: most businesses want to keep as much information as possible because they don't know when it will be useful.

column1: Third
column2: many search engines actively use this information
column3: for example to show you more targeted advertising.

column1: Another way that your searches are often tied together at other search engines are through browser cookies
column2: which are pieces of

column1: information that sit on your computer and get sent to the search engine on each request. ;NaN
What search engines often do is store a unique identifier in your browser and then associate that identifier with your searches. At DuckDuckGo
column2: no cookies are used by default.

column1: In response to efforts by the EFF and others
column2: the major search engines have begun "anonymizing" their search log data after periods of time. Sure
column3: this is better than not doing so
column4: but you should note that this does not make your search history anonymous in the same way that it is at DuckDuckGo.

column1: What search engines generally do when they anonymize data is get rid of part of your IP address or turn it into something that doesn't look
exactly like an IP address. And they do the same thing for uniquely identifying cookies.
However
column2: in many cases
column3: this so-called anonymous data can still tie your searches together
column4: which can be used to reconstruct

column1: who you are and what you searched for. Additionally
column2: search engines usually are silent on what they do with the User agent

column1: which has been shown to also have enough information to often be personally identifiable
column2: especially if isolated to a particular search session (day).;NaN

column1: INFORMATION COLLECTED
At DuckDuckGo
column2: no cookies are used by default. If you have changed any settings
column3: then cookies are used to store those changes.

column1: However
column2: in that case
column3: they are not stored in a personally identifiable way. For example
column4: the large size setting is stored as 's=l'; no unique identifier is in there. Furthermore
column5: if you prefer not to use cookies to store settings
column6: you can use URL parameters instead.

column1: Additionally
column2: if you use our !bang syntax/dropdown
column3: which bangs you use are stored in a cookie so that we can list your most frequently used

column1: ones on top of the !bang dropdown box. Just like the other settings
column2: this information is not saved on our servers at all
column3: but resides solely

column1: on your computer. There is also a setting to turn this off
column2: which you can also set via a URL parameter. Particular searches are of course not stored.;1 ;5

column1: An example cookie might look like: php=2&yelp=19&java=4.
We also save searches
column2: but again
column3: not in a personally identifiable way
column4: as we do not store IP addresses or unique User agent strings.

column1: We use aggregate
column2: non-personal search data to improve things like misspellings.

column1: Similarly
column2: we may add an affiliate code to some eCommerce sites (e.g. Amazon & eBay) that results in small commissions being paid back to DuckDuckGo when you make purchases at those sites. We do not use any third parties to do the code insertion
column3: and we do not work with any sites that share personally identifiable information (e.g. name
column4: address
column5: etc.) via their affiliate programs. This means that no information is shared from DuckDuckGo to the sites
column6: and the only information that is collected from this process is product information
column7: which is not tied to any particular user and which we do not save or store on our end. It is completely analogous to the search result case from the previous paragraph--we can see anonymous product info such that we cannot tie them to any particular person (or even tie multiple purchases together). This whole affiliate process is an attempt to keep advertising to a minimal level on DuckDuckGo.

column1: Finally
column2: if you give us feedback
column3: it may be stored in our email.

column1: However
column2: you can give anonymous feedback (by not entering your email or other personal info on the feedback form). ;NaN

column1: INFORMATION SHARED
If you turn redirects off in the settings and you don't either turn POST on or use our encrypted site
then your search could leak to sites you click on.
Yet as explained above
column2: this does not happen by default.

column1: Also
column2: like anyone else
column3: we will comply with court ordered legal requests.

column1: However
column2: in our case
column3: we don't expect any because there is nothing useful to give them since we don't collect any personal information. ;NaN

column1: OTHER
OTHER SEARCH ENGINES  [TOP]
If you care about search privacy
column2: you might also want to check out these other search engines that take it seriously by default.

column1: •	Ixquick [privacy policy]
Each does things a bit differently in terms of privacy and very differently in terms of results. And not all go as far as DuckDuckGo in some aspects. However
column2: none store your personal information by default
column3: which make them all pretty safe in our opinion.

column1: UPDATES  [TOP]
If this policy is substantively updated
column2: we will update the text of this page and provide notice to you at https://duckduckgo.com/about by writing '(Updated)' in red next to the link to this page (in the footer) for a period of at least 30 days.

column1: FEEDBACK  [TOP]
I (Gabriel Weinberg) am the founder of Duck Duck Go and personally wrote this privacy policy. If you have any questions or concerns
column2: please submit feedback.

column1: How do we protect your information?
We use PayPal to process your payments. PayPal offers the use of a secure server. All supplied sensitive information is transmitted via

Transport Layer Security (TLS) or Secure Socket Layer (SSL) technology and then encrypted into our Payment gateway providers database only to be accessible by those authorized with special access rights to such systems
column2: and are required to keep the information confidential. Please refer also to PayPal Privacy policy for details.

column1: Do we use cookies?
Yes
column2: on winscp.net we use cookies. Cookies are small files that a site or its service provider transfers to your computers hard drive through your

column1: Web browser (if you allow) that enable the sites or service providers systems to recognize your browser and capture and remember certain information.
We use cookies to compile aggregate data about site traffic and site interaction so that we can offer better site experiences and tools in the future.
Note that you can change your browser settings to disable cookies if you have privacy concerns. ;NaN

COOKIES AND WEB BEACONS
When you visit an Fruit Ninja Web Page and/or Service
column2: a cookie that uniquely identifies your browser may be sent to your computer or mobile device.

column1: A “cookie” is a small file containing your preferences that are sent to your browser and sent back by your browser each time your browser
accesses our servers. Cookies that we may use may only be read by the server that placed them there. We use cookies to improve the quality of our Service (for example
column2: by fulfilling your language
column3: filtering and other preferences) and to better understand how people interact with our Service (for example
column4: by tracking user trends and patterns of how people search). Most browsers are initially set up to accept cookies. You can reset your browser to refuse all cookies or to indicate when a cookie is being sent. However
column5: some aspects of the Service may not function properly without cookies. If you would like more information about cookies and how to control and delete cookies in various browsers

California Online Privacy Protection Act

CalOPPA is the first state law in the nation to require commercial websites and online services to post a privacy policy. The law’s reach stretches well beyond California to require any person or company in the United States (and conceivably the world) that operates websites collecting Personally Identifiable Information from California consumers to post a conspicuous privacy policy on its website stating exactly the information being collected and those individuals or companies with whom it is being shared. – See more at http://consumercal.org/california-online-privacy-protection-act-caloppa/
According to CalOPPA

column1: Fair Information Practices

The Fair Information Practices Principles form the backbone of privacy law in the United States and the concepts they include have played a significant role in the development of data protection laws around the globe. Understanding the Fair Information Practice Principles and how they should be implemented is critical to comply with the various privacy laws that protect personal information.
To be in line with Fair Information Practices we will notify you via email within 7 business days should a data breach occur.
We also agree to the Individual Redress Principle which requires that individuals have the right to legally pursue enforceable
rights against data collectors and processors who fail to adhere to the law. This principle requires not only that individuals have enforceable
rights against data users
column2: but also that individuals have recourse to courts or government agencies to investigate and/or prosecute non-compliance

column1: by data processors. ;NaN
CAN-SPAM Act
The CAN-SPAM Act is a law that sets the rules for commercial email
column2: establishes requirements for commercial messages
column3: gives recipients the right to have emails stopped from being sent to them
column4: and spells out tough penalties for violations.
